review.title: Bipolar Weighted Argumentation Graphs
review.abstract: This paper discusses the semantics of weighted argumentation graphs that are biplor, i.e. contain both attacks and support graphs. The work builds on previous work by Amgoud, Ben-Naim et. al., which presents and compares several semantics for argumentation graphs that contain only supports or only attacks relationships, respectively.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 161 1.08 572v 1 [cs.A I] 2 5This paper discusses the semantics of weighted argumentation graphs that are biplor, i.e. contain both attacks and support graphs. It builds on earlier work by Amgoud, Ben-Naim et. al. [1, 2], which presents and compares several semantics for argumentation graphs that contain only support or attack relations.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In [3] we presented a prototype of a system that allows users to explore arguments for a particular topic, which includes these steps: 1. argument identification. In the first step, arguments for a particular topic are identified in a given text and offensive and supportive relationships are established between the proposals. The result is an argumentation graph. In the future, we hope to use argumentation techniques to automate this step. At this point, this is done manually by adding some texts.2. Initial plausibility assessment. The proposals (presented as nodes of the argumentation graph) are assigned an initial plausibility based on web search engines. 3. acceptability level of the reasoning calculation is calculated. This calculation depends on the plausibility assessment of the intentions and attacks and support between themes.4. Recommendation. Based on the calculation of the acceptability level of the system, an answer and the argument for it is calculated 5. user interaction.

sections.text: However, the main intuition behind aggregation semantics is that the strength of an argument in an argumentation = = > A = = 1 "for the acceptance of this argument is based on its initial plausibility and is reinforced by support and attenuated by attack. If we understand" strengthening "as addition and" weakening "as subtraction, we arrive at a model in which the degree of acceptance of an argument is calculated by adding to its initial plausibility the sum of the degree of acceptance of its supporters and subtracting the sum of the degree of acceptance of its attacks. An additional intuition behind semantics is that the influence of arguments is strongest on arguments that directly attack or support them and increasingly weaker on arguments that are only indirectly associated with them. sections.heading: 7 Comparison to previous work
sections.text: If the classical work of dung [12] is generalized to a rank-based reasoning, Amgoud et al. [2] have introduced weighted argumentation graphs. Furthermore, they limit the weighting to [0, 1]. Therefore, they consider a non-empty finite series of arguments, a weighting w: A → [0, 1], and an attack relationship Ra A · A. Amgoud et al. also consider supportive argumentation graphs [1], which are similar except that Ra is organized into a vector by a support relationship Rs A · A. It is easy to organize A into a vector. Then, Ra and Rs can be organized as incidence matrices Ga and Gs. sections.heading: 10 Conclusion and Future work
sections.text: We have shown that bipolar argumentation graphs can be equipped with weighted (rank-based) semantics, both for weights that go beyond real numbers and for weights in the range [0, 1]. Future work should consider the following questions: • Is it possible to generalize counting in such a way that one does not consider exactly the same group of attackers, but a number of comparable attackers? • Can attack and support relationships be equipped with a strength in [− 1, 1]?
